3780 (RAP) ÓWAF
TOXICOLOGY AND APPLIED PHARMACOLOGY 111, 523-529 (1991)
Effects of Cigarette Smoke on the Immune Response
If. Chronić Exposure to Cigarette Smoke Inhibits Surface: . Immunoglobulin-Mediated Responses in B Cells'
SUSAN M. SAVAGE, LESLIE A. DONALDSON, SUSAMMA CHERIAN, RANGA CHILUKURI, VICKI A. WHITE, AND MOHAN L. SOPORI
Immunctoxicology Section, Lovelace Medical Foundation. 2425 Ridgecrest Rood, South East, Albuquerque. New Mexico 87108
Received June 17. 1991: accepted August 28. 1991
Effects of Cigarette Smoke on the Immune Response. IL. Chronic Exposure to Cigarette Smoke Inhibits Surface Immunoglobulin-Mediated Responses in B Cells. SAVAGE, S. M. DONALDSON, L. A., CHERIAN, S ... CHILL'KURI. R., WHITE. V. A .. AND SOPORL.M. L. (1991). Taxicol. Appl. Pharmacol. 111, 523-529. We have previously reported that chronic exposure of rats to cigarette smoke inhibits the antibody-forming cell (AFC) response to both T-dependent and T-independent antigens and may reflect B cell dysfunction. In this communication we extend these studies to show that T cell functions are normal in chronically smoke-exposed rats (SM) as judged by their responses to mitogens and "nominal" or alloantigens. While B cells from SM respond significantly to the B cell mitogen lipopolysaccharide (LPS], they fail to proliferate in response to anti-lgM (anti-u) or to produce significant AFC response to sheep red blood cells. On the basis of the number of rosenes formed with trinitrophenylated (TNP) horse red blood cells. the frequency of TNP-binding cells (TNP-ABC) in the spleens of SM is comparable to sham control rats. However. the proliferation of TNP-ABC to TNP-Brucella abortus is significantly decreased in SM. These differences in SM B celliresponses. i.e., between LPS and anti-u/antigen, may to be related to the ability of LPS to bypass a portion of the membrane signal transduction cascade. These results suggest that cigarette smoke affects an early step(s) in the antigen-dependent B cell signal trans- duction pathway. C 1991 Academic Press. Inc.
Cigarette smoking is known to cause im- pairment of the immune system and long- term inhalation of cigarette smoke leads to: immunosuppression in humans and animals (Holt and Keast, 1977). We have previously shown (Sopori et al., 1989) that the antibody- forming cell (AFC) response of lung-asso- ciated lymph nodes, to both T-dependent and T-independent antigens, is significantly inhibited in rats exposed to cigarette smoke for 20-25 weeks. However, with longer ex-
" This work was supported in part by grants from NIH (AI 31386) and the Council for Tobacco Research, USA (CTR-1957).
posures the immunosuppression is exhibited by other peripheral lymphoid tissues as well. Despite inhibition of the AFC response, cig- arette smoke has no significant effect on the number or ratio of B and T cells (Sopori et al., 1989). This finding suggested that either B cell and/or T cell functions are impaired following chronic exposure to cigarette smoke. In this communication we present data indicating that long-term (>55 wk) ex- posure to cigarette smoke impairs the ability of B cells to respond to the antigen-depen- dent signals necessary for their proliferation and differentiation.
0041-008X/91 $3.00 Copyright C 1991 by Academic Press, Inc. All rights of reproduction in any form reserved.

FLANDER, H., VOS, J. P .. AGEN, J., OESTREICHER, JTMAN, P., AND GISPEN, rowth-associated protein ganglia and sciatic nerve . J. Neurosci. 10, 3505-

duction pathway. C 1991 Academic Press. Inc.

Effects of Cigarette Smoke on the Immune Response. IL. Chronic Exposure to Cigarette Smoke Inhibits Surface Immunoglobulin-Mediated Responses in B Cells. SAVAGE, S. M. DONALDSON, L. A., CHERIAN, S ... CHILL'KURI. R., WHITE. V. A .. AND SOPORL.M. L. (1991). Taxicol. Appl. Pharmacol. 111, 523-529. We have previously reported that chronic exposure of rats to cigarette smoke inhibits the antibody-forming cell (AFC) response to both T-dependent and T-independent antigens and may reflect B cell dysfunction. posures the immunosuppression is exhibited by other peripheral lymphoid tissues as well.
